fields.import_code:
from sklearn.neighbors import KNeighborsClassifier
from sklearn import metrics
fields.name: KNeighborsClassifier
fields.feature_preparation:
features = dataset[[{feature_set}]]
training_set_length = int(len(features) * training_percentage)
features_train = features[:training_set_length]
features_test = features[training_set_length:]
fields.result_preparation:
results = dataset[{result}]
training_set_length = int(len(results) * training_percentage)
results_train = features[:training_set_length]
results_test = features[training_set_length:]
fields.test_accuracy:
accuracy = {}
accuracy['accuracy'] = metrics.accuracy_score(results_test, prediction, normalize=True)
accuracy['average_precision'] = metrics.average_precision_score(results_test, prediction)
accuracy['f1_score_weighted'] = metrics.f1_score(results_test, prediction, average='weighted')
accuracy['f1_score_micro'] = metrics.f1_score(results_test, prediction, average='micro')
accuracy['f1_score_macro'] = metrics.f1_score(results_test, prediction, average='macro')
accuracy['f1_score'] = metrics.f1_score(results_test, prediction, average=None)
accuracy['precision_weighted'] = metrics.precision_score(results_test, prediction, average='weighted')
accuracy['precision_micro'] = metrics.precision_score(results_test, prediction, average='micro')
accuracy['precision_macro'] = metrics.precision_score(results_test, prediction, average='macro')
accuracy['precision'] = metrics.precision_score(results_test, prediction, average=None)
accuracy['recall_weighted'] = metrics.recall_score(results_test, prediction, average='weighted')
accuracy['recall_micro'] = metrics.recall_score(results_test, prediction, average='micro')
accuracy['recall_macro'] = metrics.recall_score(results_test, prediction, average='macro')
accuracy['recall'] = metrics.recall_score(results_test, prediction, average=None)
accuracy['roc_auc'] = metrics.roc_auc_score(results_test, prediction)

fields.name: n_neighbors
fields.help: Number of neighbors to use by default for k_neighbors queries.

fields.name: weights
fields.help:
weights : str or callable

    weight function used in prediction. Possible values:

        ‘uniform’ : uniform weights. All points in each neighborhood are weighted equally.
        ‘distance’ : weight points by the inverse of their distance. in this case, closer neighbors of a query point will have a greater influence than neighbors which are further away.
        [callable] : a user-defined function which accepts an array of distances, and returns an array of the same shape containing the weights.

    Uniform weights are used by default.

fields.name: algorithm
fields.help:
algorithm : {‘auto’, ‘ball_tree’, ‘kd_tree’, ‘brute’}, optional

    Algorithm used to compute the nearest neighbors:

        ‘ball_tree’ will use BallTree
        ‘kd_tree’ will use KDTree
        ‘brute’ will use a brute-force search.
        ‘auto’ will attempt to decide the most appropriate algorithm based on the values passed to fit method.

    Note: fitting on sparse input will override the setting of this parameter, using brute force.

fields.name: leaf_size
fields.help:
leaf_size : int, optional (default = 30)

    Leaf size passed to BallTree or KDTree. This can affect the speed of the construction and query, as well as the memory required to store the tree. The optimal value depends on the nature of the problem.

fields.name: metric
fields.help:
metric : string or DistanceMetric object (default=’minkowski’)

    the distance metric to use for the tree. The default metric is minkowski, and with p=2 is equivalent to the standard Euclidean metric. See the documentation of the DistanceMetric class for a list of available metrics.

fields.name: p
fields.help:
p : integer, optional (default = 2)

    Power parameter for the Minkowski metric. When p = 1, this is equivalent to using manhattan_distance (l1), and euclidean_distance (l2) for p = 2. For arbitrary p, minkowski_distance (l_p) is used.
will attempt to decide the most appropriate algorithm based on the values passed to fit method.
uniform weights. All points in each neighborhood are weighted equally.
weight points by the inverse of their distance. in this case, closer neighbors of a query point will have a greater influence than neighbors which are further away.
